title: Blewbury - Churn Hill - East Illsley Down Walk Route

images.title: Graham Horn / Blewbury Green
images.caption: Blewbury Green. A notice and information board, a bench, a monument and a few trees. But from the map on the information board Blewbury is far more interesting than just that.

images.title: Graham Horn / Blewbury map
images.caption: Blewbury map - a handy information board and map in the village.

images.title: Bill Nicholls / View over Blewbury
images.caption: View over the village from the Tower of St Michaels church.

images.title: Andrew Smith / Churn Knob
images.caption: Churn Knob. The knob is a tumulus. The cross is there because the roots of Christianity in Wessex can purportedly be traced to here. Apparently St Birinus, who had been sent by Pope Honorius I in 634, first met King Cynegils of Wessex on this site. Nowadays an annual pilgrimage takes place from here to Dorchester Abbey at Dorchester-on-Thames (about 12 miles).

images.title: Andrew Smith / Churn Hill
images.caption: Churn Hill. The top is circled by a gallop and crowned with a clump of trees, a mast and a covered reservoir.

images.title: Graham Horn / View from Compton Downs
images.caption: A wintery view from Compton Downs. Looking north towards (at the first tree line) the gap in the downs used by the former Didcot-Newbury-Southampton railway line. Churn Farm is in the trees in the middle distance.

images.title: Colin Bates / Blewbury Church
images.caption: Church of England parish church of St Michael and All Angels, Blewbury, Oxfordshire (formerly Berkshire), viewed from the south

images.title: Colin Bates / The Barley Mow, Blewbury
images.caption: The Barley Mow now the Blueberry pub.

description: This attractive Oxfordshire based village is surrounded by public footpaths taking you to some lovely countryside and hills. This circular walk from the village climbs to Churn Hill before visiting Blewbury Down and East Ilsley Down. The walk starts in the village and heads south to climb to Churn Hill and Church Knob. The hill stands at a heigh of 160 metres providing fine views back to the village and over the surrounding area. The route then continues south passing a dismantled railway before reaching Blewbury Down. You have the option of extending the walk by descending into the neighbouring village of East Ilsley. This walk turns north to cross Compton Downs before follow a bridleway path back to Blewbury.
